(David’s boss at the cafe, Stella, hypnotizes him for fun & he doesn't even realize. She'd like to put him under in front of someone else)

On a very hot July afternoon, the cafe was pretty quiet. David was just refilling the fridge when the door opened and in came a good friend of his he hadn’t seen for a while.

“Victoria! How are you?”

David exclaimed, giving her a warm hug.

“I’m good, thanks! How’s work been?”

“Not too bad, just a bit slow today. But it’s always good to see a friendly face,” David replied with a smile.

Just then, Stella walked in from the back room.

“Well, hello there! I haven’t seen you in ages, Victoria! How have you been?” Stella asked, greeting Victoria with a hug.

“I’ve been great, thanks. How about you?”

“I can’t complain. Just keeping busy running this place,” Stella replied.

As they chatted, Stella looked over at David and got an idea.

“Hey David, do you mind if I practice my hypnotism on you? I’ve been reading up on it and I think I’m getting pretty good.”

David shrugged. “Sure, why not? I’ve never been hypnotized before.”

Stella grinned and began to swing a pocket watch back and forth in front of David’s eyes.

“Just relax and focus on the watch,” she instructed.

David stared intently at the watch as it moved back and forth.

“Your eyelids are getting heavy, David. You’re getting more and more relaxed,” Stella said in a soothing voice.

Victoria watched with interest as David’s eyes grew heavy and he slumped slightly in his chair.

“Now, David, whenever I snap my fingers, you’ll cluck like a chicken,” Stella said with a laugh.

She snapped her fingers and David suddenly let out a loud, “Cluck, cluck, cluck!”

Victoria burst out laughing as David looked around in confusion.

“What just happened?” he asked, bewildered.

Stella explained and David couldn’t believe he had been hypnotized without even realizing it.

“That’s crazy! I didn’t even feel different,” he exclaimed.

Stella grinned. “I told you I was getting good.”

Victoria looked impressed. “That was pretty amazing.”

Stella continued to practice her hypnotism on David, making him do various silly actions like singing nursery rhymes and hopping on one foot.

As they continued to have fun, Stella wondered who else she could hypnotize in front of David. She couldn’t wait to see his reaction.

conversation.content: As the days went by, David enjoyed working at Stella’s cafe. She offered to hypnotize him each morning before the doors opened, and soon he was extremely conditioned and easy to drop deep into submissive trance with a word or a finger snap from Stella. One warm day, the cafe was almost empty when one of David’s friends, Victoria, popped in to say hello and get a cuppa. (When she realizes the two are friends, Stella can’t help showing off to Victoria using a few of the post-hypnotic commands she’s implanted in David’s mind)

As soon as Victoria walked in, Stella waved her hand and David’s body immediately went rigid, standing up straight with his hands at his sides and a blank expression on his face.

“Welcome to Stella’s cafe, Victoria,” Stella said, smirking at David. “My assistant is here to serve you.”

Victoria was taken aback by David’s sudden change in demeanor, but Stella didn’t seem to notice. She continued to give David commands, making him pour Victoria a cup of tea and bring it to her table.

“Isn’t he just the perfect little servant?” Stella asked Victoria, giggling.

Victoria didn’t know how to respond. She was a little freaked out by the whole thing. She knew David was into hypnotism, but she had no idea that Stella had such control over him.

Stella continued to play with David, making him dance and sing for Victoria’s amusement. Victoria couldn’t help but feel a little jealous of the power Stella had over him.

As the day went on, Victoria couldn’t shake the feeling that something wasn’t right. She didn’t know if it was because of the hypnotism or if there was something else going on between Stella and David.

But one thing was for sure, she wouldn’t be stopping by Stella’s cafe again anytime soon.

conversation.content: Let's write a dark novel about 16yo Tom, a shy and cute boy who visits Martha, a 55yo dermatologist for his first examination. Write it from his point of view in first person. He is unnerved by her intense, hungry look as he enters the examination room.

Title: Beneath the Skin

Chapter 1: The Examination

It was the kind of chilly morning that made you think twice about leaving the warmth of your bed, but Mom was insistent. "You're getting that rash checked out, Tom. I've booked you an appointment with Dr. Martha Whelmsley. She's the best dermatologist in town." Her words were final, so at the brisk age of sixteen, I found myself trudging towards an encounter I felt was entirely unnecessary. 

The clinic was a stark contrast to the cool, gray day, with walls a blinding shade of white. A muffled sense of dread settled in my stomach as I stepped inside, the scent of antiseptic hanging heavy in the air. The receptionist had a practiced smile, the type often worn by people who had seen too much yet cared too little. She ushered me towards the examination room after I signed in, offering a standard, "The doctor will be with you shortly."

I hadn't been waiting long when the door creaked open, betraying a sense of foreboding. In stepped Dr. Whelmsley. During the short gap between the door swinging open and her body fully emerging, I had expected someone maternal, someone with a gentle touch and a reassuring smile. What I was met with was an entirely different presence.

She was tall, her back straight as a ruled line, and even from across the room her eyes seemed to hook into mine, probing, assessing. They were a pale blue, the sort of color that should've been calming but were instead sharp, almost piercing. I couldn't shake the feeling that she was hunting for something, that there was more to this examination than checking on an adolescent's skin condition.

"Hello, Tom," she said, her voice smooth and rich, "I'm Dr. Martha Whelmsley. It's good to finally meet you." Her words were polite enough, but they carried an undercurrent that I couldn't quite place. "Please, take a seat here and we can begin."

As I sat on the cold leather chair that seemed more akin to an altar than a place of healing, she donned her latex gloves with a ceremonial slowness that made my skin crawl. Despite the room's sterility, a stifled energy seemed to hover around her, and I was trapped inside it—a fly in a web.

"Now, Tom, tell me about your symptoms," she instructed, but her tone suggested she didn't really care for the mundane details of itchiness or redness. Her gaze fixated on me, not with the clinical detachment I expected, but with a hunger that made my heart race and my palms sweat.

I started to describe the mundane—how it started, the spreading, the mild itching—but words seemed to get trapped somewhere between my mind and my mouth. With every detailed question she asked, Dr. Whelmsley leaned closer, her eyes never leaving my face. The intimacy of her proximity was unnerving, her breath carrying a strange, sweet scent that reminded me of blooming flowers at the cusp of decay.

Her fingers eventually reached out to inspect the patch of troubled skin, and her touch was colder than I'd anticipated. All warmth from her hands had seemingly been siphoned away, leaving behind an unsettling iciness that seemed to suck the heat from my own body.

"It's very important to monitor these changes," she said as her fingers traced the outline of the rash. Each word she spoke felt like it carried depth I was not aware of, as if every syllable was a muted warning or a veiled promise.

I could only nod, unable to shake the sense that Dr. Whelmsley was not merely diagnosing a skin condition but unraveling something much more intimate, delving into the fears and vulnerability that lay hidden beneath the fragile surface of my flesh.

When the examination was over, and she had prescribed me some cream with the assurance of a checkup in a few weeks, I walked out of the clinic with an uneasy relief. The morning that started with a fight to leave my bed would now end with a fight to regain the comfort it once offered. But the warmth of my bed could not erase the chill that Dr. Whelmsley's intense, hungry look had embedded deep within me—a chill that whispered of more unsettling encounters to come.

Val stepped nervously onto the garden where the tea party was being held. He took in the lovely sight of the five beautiful girls sitting around the garden table chatting happily. Each one was wearing pretty dresses and colorful sandals.

Val felt slightly out of place in his unusual outfit, but he didn't let it show. With his poofy blond hair and slender figure, he cut a very different figure from everyone else. He felt like an outsider at the party.

At first, he sat quietly and shyly, barely participating in the conversation. The girls chatted about their day, gossiped about their classmates, and giggled over jokes.

All Val could do was watch and listen. But he couldn't help but notice how lovely they all looked and how they seemed to have so much fun.

Suddenly, as Juicy tried to fix the strap of her sandal, the wind swept up, blowing up her dress and revealing her bright pink panties. The girl gasped and pulled her dress down, tears streaming down her face. The girls tried to comfort her, but Juicy was too upset.

Val stepped forward and whispered softly to her, offering her his coat to cover her up, and words of kindness. He told her that it was not her fault and that she shouldn't be embarrassed.

The girls watched in surprise as Val comforted Juicy, looking every bit the perfect gentleman. They were touched by his kindness and bravery.

As the night went on, Val started to relax around the four girls. They found that they enjoyed his quiet and thoughtful nature, and they admired the way he had handled Juicy's embarrassing moment.

Val smiled, happy that he had made new friends. He might have felt out of place at the beginning of the tea party, but now he felt like he had finally found a place where he belonged.
